question: Question_09_(g)
sols:
The function \emph{f} depends on the variables \emph{x} and \emph{y}
which themselves are functions of the variable \emph{t}. We have

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
z(t) = f(x(t),y(t)) \quad\text{and}\quad x(t) = e^{3t} \quad\text{and}\quad y(t) = \sin(2t)\end{align*}
Now, using the chain rule for multivariable functions we obtain

\begin{align*}\frac{dz}{dt}(t) = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x(t),y(t))\frac{dx}{dt}(t) + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x(t),y(t))\frac{dy}{dt}(t)\end{align*}
which using the notation as in the question statement gives

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
z'(t) = f_X(x(t),y(t))\,x'(t) + f_Y\left(x(t),y(t)\right)\,y'(t)\end{align*}

Now we just want to know what's going on at \emph{t} = 0. We have

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x(0) = e^0 = 1 \quad\text{and}\quad y(0)=\sin(0)=0\end{align*} and since

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x'(t) = 3e^{3t} \quad\text{and}\quad y'(t)=2\cos(2t)\end{align*} we have

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x'(0) = 3 \quad\text{and}\quad y'(0)=2\end{align*}

So we can conclude that

\begin{align*}
z'(0) &= f_X(1,0) \cdot 3 + f_Y(1,0) \cdot 2\\
&= 3 \cdot 3 + (-1) \cdot 2\\
&= 7\end{align*}.

Notice that the provided information for $f(1,0)=0$ was unnecessary.

How does the chain rule works when dealing with functions of several
variables?
